newsitem.title: CHINA: China trains speed up to attract passengers.
newsitem.headline: China trains speed up to attract passengers.

text.p: China's rail system entered the marketplace on Tuesday when trains started to run faster to try to win back passengers who have switched to buses and planes for speed and comfort.

Trains on three major lines -- between Beijing and the southern boomtown of Guangzhou, between Beijing and Shanghai, and Beijing and northeastern Harbin -- will run at a maximum speed of 140 kph (84 mph), the Ministry of Railways said.
Trains on other lines will reach a maximum speed of 120 kph (72 mph), the ministry said.

The move accelerates the average speed of China's lumbering trains from the current 48.1-54.9 kph (28.8-33 mph) and the maximum speed of long-distance passenger trains from 97.6 kph (58.5 mph), it said.
The move was part of a campaign to win back travellers, many of whom in recent years have changed to buses and airlines for speed and comfort, the ministry said.
A train journey from Beijing to Shanghai will now take about 15 hours, compared with the previous 17-1/2 hours, officials said.
Trains, once the transport of choice among millions of Chinese, have lost out in recent years to rapidly developing bus and airline services.
